initial_posts.text:
American football should be banned.

  Football is very popular and a critical part of many communities.
The institution of American football alienates many communities.
The institution of American football promotes problematic gender roles, alienating people who do not conform to them.
American football promotes a form of masculinity  that is harmful.
Jim Harbaugh  and Rush Limbaugh  argue that American football is the last hope for keeping American men tough.
A player formerly coached by Jim Harbauge  claims that Harbauge was unreasonable and often pushed players too hard.
The toxic masculinity  promoted by American football often leads players to take unnecessary risks.
The NFL has a long history of homophobia .
The institution of American football alienates people from many cultures through cultural appropriation .
Several NFL team mascots, chants, and celebrations appropriate Native American  culture.
The Kansas City Chiefs  begin their games with chants, dances, and face paint appropriated from Native American culture.
Many of the names and mascots of college football organizations appropriate  indigenous cultures.
Youth football  organizations regularly base their names and mascots on indigenous cultures.
Cultural appropriation and alienation are not unique  to American football.
Cultural appropriation  should not be seen as problematic. Popular activities have always involved borrowing and adapting elements of other cultures.
Cultural appropriation  is problematic when a dominant culture appropriates elements of a vulnerable minority culture.
Cultural appropriation  in American football typically involves the dominant American culture appropriating elements of vulnerable indigenous cultures.
The NCAA has an Office of Inclusion , which promotes diversity and inclusion in college athletics programs.
The NCAA diversity and inclusion initiatives were started relatively recently , which suggests that the changes are still ongoing.
The NFL promotes diversity and inclusion by partnering with the You Can Play  organization, which promotes LGBTQ+ inclusion and representation in sports.
Many of the inclusion efforts of the NFL were enacted as recently as May 2020 , which suggests that more change is necessary.
College football programs contribute significantly to the identity and brand of universities in the United States.
A lot of the typical American college experience  is built around the college football team.
Some large universities  do not have college football teams, yet still provide an American college experience.
Many schools have community based events like tailgates  and parties before or after football games, which are essential for the enjoyment of students and their college experience.
Tailgating is associated  with excessive drinking and other dangerous activities.
Interuniversity football rivalries  form the core identity of many colleges.
A connection to the college football team can build strong alumni networks  that continue to support the college after graduation.
Many colleges center their homecoming celebration  around a football game.
While it is true that football programs are core to the identity of many universities , this connection is not necessary and can be severed.
Severing the connection between a football program and the college experience can fail. For example, University of Alabama at Birmingham reinstated  football shortly after dropping it.
Importantly, the football program at Alabama Birmingham was dropped for political and financial reasons, and not for moral ones.
Decoupling football programs from college identity would fundamentally change the college experience, making it less fulfilling for many students.
Saying that decoupling football programs from college identity would fundamentally change the college experience overstates the impact on the college experience.
College football attendance is declining .
In 1901, the MIT student body voted 119-117 to discontinue  the intercollegiate football squad.
In 1978, a group of students self-organized to re-establish  the MIT team.
University mission statements that define the core identity of the university do not mention football. This is true even for universities that are famous for their football programs.
The University of Alabama 's mission statement puts emphasis "...on quality programs in the areas of teaching, research and service" without mentioning football.
The mission of the University of Oklahoma  is to provide the best possible educational experience. This has no relationship to football.
The Ohio State University's core values  do not include football or competitive sports.
Mission statements at universities often present and articulate a world view that is narrow, shallow, irrelevant and devoid of meaning .
College football is the main source of entertainment  in many small towns.
Professional football organizations contribute to the identity of the cities and states that they affiliated with.
Professional football organizations shape , and are shaped by , the culture of the city they are based in.
Celebrations after the Philadelphia Eagles' 2018 Super Bowl  victory disintegrated into rioting and looting, ultimately costing the city thousands of dollars in damages.
Communities are capable of changing, and can support other sports or cultural activities.
There are long traditions supporting baseball  and basketball  in many communities, and this could be shared with new communities.
High school football programs are important for small towns and communities.
Student athletes playing for a high school team represent the communities  they live in. This inspires a sense of honor and responsibility to perform well and come together as a team.

Camaraderie and togetherness are the most prevalent in competitions against rival schools. Rivalries  are often built upon long traditions that give players a sense of being a part of something greater than themselves.
High school football programs are associated with harmful things like hazing and aggression.
A national hazing  scandal originated from New Jersey in 2014, "where six players accused of sexually brutalizing former teammates were sentenced to 50 hours of community service."
In 2015, a group of parents of players in Southern California forcibly entered a high school locker room in order to attack students in retaliation  for an incident in a football game.
High school football is more beneficial than harmful.
High school football improves the educational opportunities of student athletes.
High school varsity and junior varsity student athletes tend to get lower English and history grades  during active sports seasons.
Some student athletes who might otherwise have dropped out  of high school stay in school instead and graduate because of football.
High school football enables athletes to compete for scholarships  that could give them a great college education.
High school football programs are uniquely ill-equipped  to manage the health risks associated with playing the game.
High school athletic programs often lack certified athletic trainers capable of advising students when to take breaks or continue playing.

There was no certified athletic trainer present at Coahoma County High School to prevent Dennis Mitchell  from re-entering the game after taking a hard hit and vomiting. He later collapsed on the field and died as a result.
Rather than banning high school football programs, they should be reformed and given additional funding to deal with any health problems that arise.
It is difficult  to weigh the harm of football for a young athlete against the benefits, given that the potential for long-term harm varies.
High school football gives young kids lessons  in teamwork, hard work, and sportsmanship that they otherwise would not learn in classrooms.
Evidence suggests that character building  and good judgment follow from participation in music, theater, and community service programs, but not from participation in sports.
High school football teams help discover and hone athletic talents in students who would otherwise go untrained.
High school football is good for students who are not directly involved with their school's team.
Students go to games together, cheer their team on together and follow their teams to away games. This strengthens relationships and builds a unique sense of camaraderie.
Passion for high school football forms a culture that is inherently exclusionary to the students who do not want to follow the sport.
The exclusionary culture of football is not specific to football. It can surround any competitive high school sport or extra curricular activity.
American football is too dangerous to permit league football.
Traumatic brain and spinal injuries are more common in football than in any other sport.
A 1994 study found that spinal cord injuries are most common  in swimming and gymnastics, rather than American football.
Nearly  51% of sports-related spinal cord injuries that were recorded occurred while swimming.
The 1994  study is based on a very small and non-representative sample population (N = 31), and thus the results should not be generalized.
Football players are at risk of catastrophic  spinal cord injuries, which are significant life-changing events and can sometimes result in death.
Darryl Stingley 's career as a receiver for the New England Patriots was cut short because of a head-on collision with Oakland Raider safety Jack Tatum, rendering him paralyzed from the neck down.
Catastrophic injuries are increasingly rare  in American football, with deaths caused directly by football significantly declining over the decades.

Football is associated with chronic traumatic encephalopathy  (CTE), which is a neurodegenerative disease found in people with multiple head injuries that typically entails behavioral, emotional, and cognitive difficulties.
The long term effects of multiple head injuries, including whether it leads to CTE, have still not been explored  sufficiently to establish that there is a causal link.
One large study  found that 110 out of 111 (99%) deceased NFL players had chronic traumatic encephalopathy.
The sample that showed widespread chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) suffered from selection bias . The players who donated their brains to the study were the ones experiencing cognitive issues.
The rate of depression  for former football players who suffered from concussions is much higher than for other former athletes.
In the United States, severe head injuries in sports are most commonly associated  with American football, and a reported 90% of cases are acute subdural hematomas (ASDH).
In 2009, the number of estimated head injuries for cycling was nearly double  the head injuries associated with football.
The number of cases of ASDH is increasing  annually.
In the United States, almost all patients with ASDH due to sport-related head injuries are senior high school students or younger .
Severe head injuries are prevalent in many other  contact sports such as rugby, boxing, judo, ice hockey, skiing, and snowboarding.
American football is a contact sport that results in acute injuries that harm players over their lifetime.
Minor injuries and concussions are common in American Football.
Concussions are common  in professional American Football.
The 2012  and 2016  International Conferences on Concussion in Sports found that the data connecting repeated concussions and long-term health issues is inconclusive.
Even if the literature on long-term consequences is inconclusive, this does not mean that there is no evidence of long-term consequences.
The grueling nature of the sport includes constant high intensity practice which can become dangerous  for football players.
Football players are capable of great feats of strength  and athleticism as a result of the intensity of football practice and competition.
Football leagues could reduce  the number of heat-related issues by limiting the number of games and practices during hot and humid times of the year.
Football programs could reduce the exposure of players to dangerous temperatures by investing in enclosed  stadiums and indoor practice facilities.
Football players often have to use dangerous amounts of painkillers  simply to survive the season.
On average, former NFL players (even relatively young former players) have disproportionately  high levels of whole-person impairment (WPI) due to muscular-skeletal damage.
Professional players lose, on average, three years  of life expectancy for every year they play professional football.
Playing football prior to age 12 is associated  with long-term health consequences.

Studies that compared recreational football players to those with alternative pastimes during their childhood found that there was no difference  in numbers of adults from each group who went on to develop neurodegenerative illnesses.
The rate of dementia at 50 years of age is 5 times  higher among men who played American football than men who did not.
People should be able to voluntarily participate in dangerous activities so long as everyone's participation is voluntary.
The ability to engage in dangerous acts is fundamental to our freedom  and autonomy.
People should only be free to take on reasonable risks, but the risk involved in football is unreasonable.
The NFL and other American football associations have not been honest about the risk of playing. People cannot meaningfully agree to risks they do not know.

That the NFL and other organizations have misstated the dangers of football is not an argument to ban these organizations, but instead to regulate them so that they are required to disclose the risks involved.
The NFL tried to cover up  the long-term brain damage caused by American football multiple times.
The medical professional appointed by the NFL who downplayed the risks of CTE, Dr. Elliot Pellman , was forced into retirement.
While Dr. Pellman was identified as a controversial figure  in 1994, he continued to work in the NFL for 30 years and retired in 2016.
The documentary 'League of Denial' details  two decades of the NFL's efforts to suppress research on health impacts of football, and discredit research  that made it into the public sphere.
The documentary has had little impact  on the popularity of professional football and TV ratings  of the NFL. This suggests that the findings are not compelling.

The suppression effort affected  the documentary itself. A campaign was launched to label the film as biased, which ultimately resulted in the NFL and ESPN breaking ties with PBS once the trailer for the documentary was released.
The researcher who discovered CTE, Dr. Omalu, was the target of a smear campaign  by the NFL, ultimately forcing him to leave his job.

The campaign  to suppress the health impacts of football slowed down, and halted, much research being completed, and made available to the public. In the decades of this campaign many more athletes incurred damaging, life-threatening, and even fatal, injuries.
It is possible that long-term brain damage information was simply mismanaged by the NFL due to incompetent leadership.
Paul Tagliabue , the commissioner of the NFL from 1989 to 2006, used his position to publicly downplay the risks of brain injury in the NFL.
The incompetence of other organizations does not absolve the NFL of culpability for its actions.
For example, the NFLPA  (NFL Players Association) failed to represent the interests of the players by working to minimize long-term brain damage.
A congressional report issued in 2016 indicated that the NFL used their funding of concussion research to try to influence  the results of that research.

While people should know risks before they consent, one can set the bar too high. There will always be unknowns and it is fairly obvious that football involves the potential for very serious physical injuries.
Former college athletes report  that they didn't feel able to discuss the extent of their injuries and didn't feel that their coaches were sufficiently honest with them.
A 2018 lawsuit against  the NCAA alleged that it knew the risks associated with repeated head trauma and did not adequately disclose these risks.

What counts as a reasonable or unreasonable risk should be determined by the person taking the risk. Thus, the distinction between reasonable and unreasonable risk is irrelevant in deciding when to limit freedom.
Americans identify individual freedom  as an essential virtue for living as an American.
People should not have the ability to exercise their autonomy to undertake actions that could be detrimental to their self interest.
People are not allowed to not wear seat-belts while driving because it is against their own interest to do so.

Paternalism  (the view that society can force or prohibit certain actions for the good of the individual) is generally held to be of limited value in democratic societies, only to be allowed when all the relevant information cannot be communicated to the individual.
Adults have the authority and capacity to consensually engage in many risky activities. Football is no different.

Adults are allowed to participate in a host of dangerous activities for pleasure, such as mixed martial arts (MMA), wrestling, boxing, sword fighting , skydiving, cabling and rappelling, caving, cliff jumping and base jumping.
There are reports of paralysis  and other severe injuries  arising from the play of rugby, but there's no call to ban rugby as a sport.
While American football is a sport that carries risks to participants, other sports  that are widely enjoyed are more dangerous than American football.

Even if other sports are more dangerous than American football, it doesn't follow that American football is safe and should not be banned. It may be the case that all sports as dangerous as American football should be banned.
Skiing, equestrian  sports, and cycling have been deemed  more dangerous than American football.
The extent to which American football permeates the day to day life of the average American makes it unique in terms of the scope and degree of harm it can cause.
An activity's degree of popularity has no effect on its level of safety. If such hazardous activities are legal for the general public, football should be as well.
Children are too young to meaningfully understand and consent to the potential long-term damage of football.
Parental consent is required for children to play competitive football. Legally and morally this is sufficient to avoid the charge that children can't meaningfully agree to play.
Many low-income families are coerced to have their children play football because they view it as a means of creating economic opportunities  for their children.
Paternalism  is justifiable when dealing with non-adults. Thus, it is acceptable for society to restrict even voluntary actions such as choosing to participate in youth football.

Risky behavior is more likely  when peer pressure is involved, particularly among teens and young adults. This makes it hard to say that participation is truly voluntary in an incredibly popular activity like playing football.
The costs of the risks of football are externalized to the rest of society through the cost of health care. Thus it shouldn't be allowed.

The setup of the American health system means the cost of sports injuries is not borne by society, but instead athletes are covered by team or university insurance plans, or the athlete themselves bears the high costs  of recovery.
The NFL alone  is a multi-billion dollar contributor to the economy. It can afford to pay the health costs of professional football.
The NFL has not shown a willingness to pay  its long term health costs. They thus became borne by society more broadly.
Given that most college football programs already lose  money they will not be able to pay the costs of adequate medical care. Thus, these costs will be covered by society.
It is a common practice  for college teams to drop injured players from the team and then refuse to cover their healthcare.
A person's liberty to engage in risky behaviors is limited by the risk it puts on other people.
An individual is not allowed to drive drunk because they might harm someone else.
All of society is put at risk by the high health risks associated with football.
Condoning dangerous activities normalizes risks, thus increasing the instances of risky behavior and risk related injury. Any increase in injuries increases the cost of health care.
Famous athletes are commonly glorified in advertisements  and thus often recognized as examples of what young athletes should strive to become.
The NFL has invested in preventing , diagnosing and treating head injuries.
The NFL has a large and politically active lobbying  wing that tries to downplay the link between injury and the sport.
In 2018, the NFL responded to a 'call to action' from their chief medical officer by immediately  launching a comprehensive Injury Reduction Plan.
In 2019 , the NFL released data that indicated a slight increase in diagnosed concussions from the 2018 season. This suggests that the NFL is committed to transparency.
NFL sponsored research omitted  the results of over 100  concussions to influence the results of the research.
In 2017 the NFL announced a $100 million  concussion initiative aimed at making the game safer.
The NFL launched the Head Health Challenge , a competition to encourage companies to study and develop products to improve player safety.
Reforming the way football is played would be preferable to a ban.
While reforming American football might be an alternative to banning it outright, actually doing so is prohibitively difficult.
The organizations that govern American football have shown themselves to be resistant to change in the past. This suggests that reform in the future will also be incredibly difficult.
Close to a century of attempts to reform college football have failed .
The NFL  has continued to change rules and implement better sideline procedures nearly every year since 1985 to make the game safer.
While most Americans support making football safer, NFL fans largely reject  the proposed changes to the game. This likely limits the NFL's willingness to make meaningful changes.
Football has become safer because of the innovations in protective gear in the 1960's and 1990's.
Shoulder pads  began to be manufactured from plastic materials in the 1960s and 1970s, which improved their effectiveness.
The use of plastic in the 1960's led to the development  of the sleek and efficient shoulder pads in the 1990's.
While protective gear has improved in the last fifty years, players have also gotten  bigger and faster. This greatly increases the danger from head-on collisions.
The NFL has asserted  that rule changes have yielded measurable results in safety.

Removal of the three-point stance , in which a lineman crouches with his hand on the ground, allowing him to launch himself at the opposing lineman, should greatly decrease the impacts over an athleteâ€™s career.
Linemen absorb many hundreds of repetitive subconcussive  impacts each season, which is largely why many of the former NFL players diagnosed with CTE have been offensive and defensive linemen.

In 2018, the NFL prohibited the lowering helmets to initiate contact with their opponents (The Helmet Rule), and initial data  suggests that there was a significant reduction (20%) in concussions caused by an opponent lowering their helmets.
The Helmet Rule directly outlaws helmet-to-helmet  contact, which accounts for 40 - 50% of all concussions in the NFL.
The fact that so many NFL players have objected  to the Helmet Rule suggests that it has not actually improved the game overall.
The NFL itself admits  that there is insufficient data to suggest that rule changes caused the 2017-2018 concussion reduction.

A 2020 study  analyzing the effectiveness of new NFL procedures on orthopedic and brain injuries from 2009 to 2019 found that the changes to the game have had no significant impact on the safety of players.
Banning competitive play altogether will always lead to a greater reduction in severe injuries than simply reforming the rules.
The burden of proof is on those who argue that these rule changes will make the game sufficiently safe.
Some have argued that banning parts of the game, like wearing pads  and helmets , would make the game significantly safer.
Increased protection, neck training, and changing the location of kick offs are all examples of changes  that have been implemented to increase safety for players.

According to the NCAA , heart issues, heat illness, and respiratory conditions are some of the top causes of death among football players. These deaths can be prevented without changing the rules of the game.
Heart issues, heat illness, and respiratory conditions are complicated by environmental  factors like temperature and humidity. These environmental factors can be manipulated, making the game safer.
While environmental factors do contribute to heat-related illnesses, the intense physical exertion required to play and practice American football is also a known cause .
Heat-related complications can be managed  by controlling the pace of football games and by reducing the continuous amount of time any particular player is on the field.

The protective padding  necessary to keep football players safe from physical impacts drastically increases body temperature, which puts players at risk for heat-related illnesses. This danger is thus unavoidable.

Football linemen  typically have large body mass indexes (BMIs), putting them at an increased risk of suffering heat stroke and other heat-related illnesses. There is thus no easy way to prevent this risk.
Performance enhancing supplements  and substance abuse increase the risk of heat-related illness and can be regulated without significantly changing how American football is played.
The kinds of supplements and medications that interact with the extreme physical exertion of playing football are not well known, and thus are difficult to control.
In 2009 , a 15-year-old lineman in Kentucky collapsed and later died because of an unexpected interaction between his medication and high school football practice.
It is not possible to reform American football to make it safe enough to play.
There is no way to eliminate brain injury from the sport because there is no way to prevent harm inside the skull.
While some degree of head injury may be endemic to contact sports, worst case scenarios like concussions and chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) can be mitigated through preventative measures.
There is intensive research  into shock absorbing materials that could be used to line helmets in the future.
While preventative measures are effective for reducing head injuries, they cannot mitigate chronic traumatic encephalopathy  (CTE)
The dangers of injury and death in car accidents are an analogous case. Modern technology has mitigated the risk of injury and death significantly. The same can be done for football.
Cars and other automobiles are necessary for living in a modern society. American football is a game and is thus inessential.
There are many activities with a degree of risk that can't be fully eliminated. In such cases, risk is mitigated to an agreed upon degree, and the activity is continued.

Saying that any possibility of harm to the skull must be removed is an unnecessarily high burden. By this logic, injury and risk is inherent to many activities and sports and all ought be banned. Clearly this is not the case.
While injury and risk are inherent, the argument under consideration here is that the injuries one risks by playing American football are significantly worse than others.
A sudden stop  is all it takes to cause an injury.

No matter the extent to which rules are changed, American football will always remain a contact sport that encourages players implicitly to hurt their opposition. This is systemic to the nature of the sport.
As long as American football plays some social good, it is better to try to eliminate the harm while retaining the good than it is to eliminate both.
Football promotes the social goods of athleticism and competition.
Other athletic activities promote athleticism and competition without nearly as many risks.
Tennis, baseball, and basketball all promote athleticism and competition without nearly as much risk as American football.
Football promotes unhealthy forms of athleticism and competition.
The discipline and athleticism of professional football enables players to compete in the Olympics .
Unhealthy levels of competition, especially at younger ages, can have detrimental impact on young players' mental health .
Amateur and highschool football teams don't have the finances or public infrastructure to give athletes the levels of support they require.
Intense pressure and competitiveness causes early burnout in athletes. This can happen at ages as low as 9 or 10 .

This is an argument that the pressure and competitiveness of football should be limited, especially for younger players. This point does not mean that football necessarily requires intense pressure and competitiveness.
Football encourages holistic development of students when they are in middle school, high school, and college.
While football may promote holistic development, in practice this holistic development is subordinated to the economic payoffs associated with football.
There is a positive correlation  between college academic performance and participation in college level sports.
There are high opportunity costs  associated with being a student athlete.
College sports scholarships are highly competitive  and often require sacrificing time and energy that could be spent on non-athletic activities in order to have any chance of winning.
Football helps students and teachers value leadership  and fitness  as important and essential for growth.
American football players set a negative example for the rest of society.
Football's declining  popularity makes a ban unnecessary.
High school football has been declining  in popularity for close to a decade. In the long-term this will lead to declines in college football and professional football as well.
Even if the trend in declining numbers of high school players continues, there will still  be more than enough high school students who play football to recruit into college football and the NFL.
The popularity  of the Superbowl has been declining for years. It is reasonable to predict that it will continue to do so.
In 2020 , Superbowl viewership increased rather than decreased.
If football is judged to be too problematic, it should be banned irrespective of its declining popularity.
The rise of the popularity of other sports means that football will lose its preeminent place whether or not football is banned.
Soccer is becoming increasingly popular  in the United States. This can be expected to continue and have an impact on the popularity of American football.
The NBA's rising popularity  is coming at the expense of the NFL, and this can be expected to continue.
Because people follow different sports at different times of the year, the popularity of sports is not necessarily a zero sum game.
While some data suggests that football is becoming less popular , there is not enough data available to conclude that this is a long-term trend.

Boxing went from being  one of the most popular sports in America to a niche sport, at least in part because of concern  over the commonality of concussions. It is reasonable that the same will happen to football regardless of whether or not it is banned.
While boxing might have declined in popularity, mixed martial arts (MMA ) has soared in popularity. This suggests the public is perfectly comfortable with violence in sports.
The organizations that promote football are exploitative.
If adult players agree to play on a football team, then they are not being exploited.
The power differential between players on the one hand and teams and leagues on the other is sufficient that agreements can be exploitative.
Accepting payment below the minimum wage  because it is the only option is a decision an adult can make, but society still recognizes it as exploitative and puts in place measures to rectify it.
Agreeing to join a football team or organization entails consenting to the rules and expectations associated with the sport.
Banning football will not address problems of exploitation because it affects all professional and collegiate sports.
Professional football players are the only  major-sport athletes in the US to not have guaranteed contracts.

Not having guaranteed contracts means that if players are injured or have a bad season, they are not guaranteed a spot in the next line up, which forces players to ignore their physical and mental health in order to keep their job.
NFL players play on average  for only two and a half years.
The NCAA rules that prohibit athletes to be paid apply to all college athletes, not just college football players.

That the NCAA forces many college athletes to play full time with little to no compensation might be a reason to say that other sports are also exploitative, but it is irrelevant to the question of whether college football is exploitative.
College football generates by far the most revenue  of any college sport. The rule against paying college football players is thus particularly exploitative.
The National Football League (NFL) exploits its players.
The NFL could be reformed  so that it is no longer exploitative.
Professional football players are very well compensated for their participation and are not compelled to remain football players.
Even with the earnings they get, many football players go bankrupt .
Football players often end up unable to work  in other industries because of the injuries they suffer during their career.
The minimum salary  in the NFL is $480,000. That places every NFL player in the top 1%  of income earners.
The median  salary of an NFL player is around $860,000.
NFL team owners likely each make hundreds of millions of dollars in profit in excess of what they play their players.
The Green Bay Packers regularly report  receiving a share of national revenue in excess of the NFL payroll cap by around 50 million.
Estimates of operating incomes  (which effectively equate with profit) for each team range from a low of 28 million to a high of 420 million.

While the amount of surplus value generated by a relatively small number of coaches and team owners might be particularly high, the extraction of surplus value  from labor is common under capitalism, and is not unique to football.
Coaches, janitorial staff, web developers, stadium and player managers, advertisers and doctors have jobs because of the popularity and scale of the NFL.

The fact  that NFL owners, CEO's and head coaches are almost exclusively white, whereas players are overwhelmingly non-white, makes the extraction of surplus value in American football particularly problematic.
Various rent seeking  activities and the tax-status  of the NFL represent departures from the free market that justifies the appropriation of surplus value in capitalist systems.

The supposedly rent seeking activities of the NFL are better understood as a form of public-private partnership , in which private entities and the state cooperate for the mutual benefit of both sides.
By far the largest piece of fixed capital  that a team has is its stadium. But the NFL and its team ownership tend to pass the cost of this capital to the public.

For example, to attract the NFL's Cleveland Browns  in 1995, the state of Maryland agreed to build a new stadium in Baltimore and allow the team to use it rent-free and keep all parking, advertising, and concession revenue.
College football is exploitative.
Most top-level college football players are on year-to-year scholarships  that can be revoked for any reason.
Because players are on yearly contracts, they can be coerced into playing injured or skipping class to appease the coach.
The NCAA uses strict regulations  to force college athletes in all sports to play full time while getting little to no compensation.
27 schools collect more than $100 million  in revenue from football, and players cannot play if they accept any form of compensation.
College football players are forced to sign away  the rights to their names and likenesses.
Fewer  than 2% of college football players go onto play for the NFL. Since the NCAA does not pay student athletes, the other 98% will see no financial benefit from playing college football.
Division I college football players spend an average of 43.2 hours  a week training and playing.
The primary compensation that student athletes get is an education, often free or at very little cost. If students decide this is worth it to them, they should be free to make that decision.
Like all intramural activities, college football is amateur . Thus, there is no reason college football players should expect compensation.
The way that the NCAA treats its commitment to amateurism is riddled with inconsistencies .
College football provides more benefits than harms for college athletes.
Football scholarships enable student athletes to get into top academic programs that they otherwise would not have access to.
Players are often forced into easy majors to increase their GPAs, in a tactic known as majoring in eligibility.

By taking easier classes and less rigorous majors, student athletes often fail to develop skills that they can fall back on if they are injured or decide not to pursue a career in professional sports.
It is misleading to characterize some majors and classes as easier than others when each major and class are different and likely require different skills.
College athletes associated with football are respected members of the college community.
College athletes affiliated with football use their positions to get away with  committing crimes like sexual assault on campus.
Florida State University had a policy of protecting football players internally  and from the law .
Studies  of Division I universities have shown that athletes, and particularly football players, account for a disproportionately large number of sexual misconduct cases.
Baylor University is alleged to have covered up, at minimum, 52 reported rapes  in 4 years by their football players.

Even if student athletes do use their positions to get away with crimes, this is evidence that student disciplinary policies should be changed rather than evidence that college football is problematic.
The institution of American football is socially harmful.
There are many examples of professional football players acting as successful role models  for their communities and using their fame to raise awareness  for important social issues.
The NFL has a vested interest  in keeping players from speaking about controversial issues. This limits the ability of players to advocate for important social issues.
Colin Kaepernick  was able to generate valuable public discourse on institutional racism in the United States by refusing to stand for the national anthem at NFL games.
Despite being a very desirable quarterback, Kaepernick has been essentially blacklisted by NFL owners, and cannot receive a contract .
Whether or not the NFL has supported Kaepernick's actions, his prominence and ability to support Black Lives Matter was made possible because of his fame as a football player.
Through programs such as the NFL's mentor program (NFLPA ), many football players have become role models to young children of similar backgrounds to their own.
